ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course covered a huge range of significant western philosophical thinkers from Plato to modernity, all focused on truth. The essays were very broad and interpretative and really pushed me to figure out my writing style and creative voice as well.
I learned how to close read and understand really complicated texts. I also better understood the role of truth in society and how that has changed over time.

I learned so much about the historical trajectory of truth and post-truth, both from an epistemological/ontological perspective, but also a normative perspective. I learned about basic philosophy (Descartes, Kant, Husserl, etc), and the ability to actually read the authors. I also got the chance to write really interesting papers which explored truth, lies, and post-truth from a variety of interesting perspectives.
Great understanding of existential philosophy and epistemology along with Post-Truth in Russia.
Knowledge of philosophy and philosophers
I definitely got a lot better at reading very dense, very convoluted philosophical texts. I also gained some sophistication in my ability to think very abstractly.

I learned about the progression of intellectual history in Eastern Europe as a whole along with the theories of individual philosophers. Also, I gained the vocabulary to discuss those changes and analyze them.
Learned about the history of truth by reading various philosophical texts. Improved critical thinking skills by engaging with difficult texts and discussing them in class.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The major strength of this course is that when theres a difficult reading Professor Shore does an incredible job of explaining the difficult concepts.

Strengths: the reading responses really make you think about the text and begin forming arguments about it. They definitely helped me engage the text more seriously.

Weaknesses: This is probably a consequence of zoom, but it felt like our discussions were aimless sometimes. I think we would have had more engagement if we had specific questions to answer, rather than general remarks on the reading. For example, if we started with comprehension questions, then comparative questions, etc, then we would have easier questions to answer at the start, which would warm people up, let them start articulating their thoughts out loud, and then the latter half of the discussion would flow more naturally.

Strengths: Readings. The readings are terrific, interesting, and diverse. Some are challenging, but getting through them is rewarding. Professor Shore is also really great. The paper assignments really let me explore non-traditional avenues for writing, which I enjoyed.

Weaknesses: Sometimes it felt like the discussion was stalling, but I think it was really a Zoom issue because it was awkward. Sometimes people would try to talk at the same time, that kind of thing. I could see how the discussion could easily go on and on in person.
I like the freedom of an open discussion, but a more structured class format could possibly be helpful.
Great course material. Was expecting it to be more existential rather than political but I'm glad that we covered both.

Strengths: great instructor, incredibly interesting topic
Weaknesses: none that I can think of!
This course was absolutely fascinating. It had a nice amount of guidance and discussion, so that it really felt our conversations were productive.
Very compelling collection of texts which kept me engaged. They were sometimes a bit long and tough to digest, however. Might be helpful to have shorter segments.

The material was very interesting and engaging. However, I found that conversation over zoom was not always super productive. The stakes felt high and most students did not feel very comfortable talking (or so was my feeling). Despite Prof. Shore's efforts, there was a certain formality that prevented me from speaking as much as I wanted to.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Shore was very understanding of zoom or covid related issues, and this helped our discussions feel like they were natural and casual.
Mostly answered by previous questions.

Discussion posts on canvas were a great way to help understand the readings through seeing the ideas of classmates. It was a great feeling to see classmates talking about the same thing that you just read and answering one another's questions.
Well done by professor! Great course.

Before class, we all had to comment on a discussion board. At times, this felt a little bit onerous -- it always took me ~way~ longer than I expected to craft my discussion post -- but it legitimately was very helpful to see what other people were thinking, so overall I'm glad we had it. I remember the professor saying that in the past she had students keep a journal, but honestly I think the discussion board might be more valuable, just because it gives everyone a chance to interact with each other's thoughts and ideas before we discuss the readings in class.
I liked having live classes twice a week! (Maybe more breakout rooms would have been nice)
Live lectures were engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, absolutely. The course covers a lot of history and philosophy without presupposing any knowledge, and the discussions are genuinely interesting and engaging.
I think this course was very good but would be much better in person. Someone who enjoys reading difficult texts and writing creatively would enjoy this class.

Absolutely. It was a bit weird over Zoom, but I'm sure in a live setting that it would an even more engaging and interesting course. Professor Shore is a great professor, gives excellent feedback, and explains certain difficult points really well. It's also not a philosophy class, but rather a history class, so it's a great way to engage with philosophy from a historical perspective...I think that it made the philosophy much more approachable. If you're not totally into philosophy at all, there are also plenty of readings that are narratives, summaries, opinions, and other academic work (e.g. language of propaganda). We also had some guest speakers, which is super cool.

Yes, a great course to take if you are curious about the nature of our existence. How can we know that we are real? Very interesting topics that might leave you bummed out after realizing there are no clear answers, however.
Yes!

Yes, I definitely would! The content was fascinating, and the professor was fantastic -- she was very kind, she facilitated a low-stakes and comfortable discussion environment, and she always had plenty of fun and interesting anecdotes on hand to use during lulls in the conversation. This is definitely a course that I will look back on fondly. While the readings could take a while, the vast majority of them were of a reasonable size, which I appreciated. Oftentimes, classes give readings so large that you can't possible find time to read all of it, forcing you to skim them and lose a lot of detail, but I rarely had to do that with this class. I took a bit of a gamble on this course, because it required me to wake up for a 6am class (yay covid), but looking back I'm very glad I chose to take it.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone whether they are interested in philosophy or not! You learn so much about yourself through the course and have fun in the process!
Yes! Most students will gain something useful from this course, be it a new perspective on truth or stronger thinking skills.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Reading responses on canvas.
